content.definition: Stenosis or occlusion of the vertebral arteries, most commonly at the origin (V1 segment) due to atherosclerosis. Contributes to vertebrobasilar insufficiency causing posterior circulation symptoms. May be asymptomatic due to collateral flow via contralateral vertebral and circle of Willis.

anatomy.V1_segment: Origin to transverse foramen C6 (most common disease site)

provocative_maneuvers: Bow Hunter syndrome: symptoms with head rotation
diagnosis: Duplex ultrasound with vertebral artery interrogation
CTA or MRA of head and neck
management: Medical therapy: antiplatelet, statin, risk factor modification
Vertebral artery transposition to common carotid

clinical_pearls: V1 origin disease most amenable to intervention
Contralateral vertebral and posterior communicating arteries provide collateral
Isolated unilateral vertebral stenosis often asymptomatic
Bow Hunter syndrome = dynamic V3 compression with head rotation
Stenting preferred for origin lesions; surgery for mid-segment
